results.title: Winners : Quest beyond time (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A flight on his hang glider sends Mike 500 years into a post-nuclear Dark Age. When a Chieftain tells him of the Holocaust he’s convinced he’s landed in a lunatic asylum. The Clan Murray are victims of the Sickness and Mike agrees to accompany a young woman warrior on a quest with many dangers. Finally they must cross a sea of nuclear waste to find a cure. Part of the “Winners” series.

results.title: Winners : On Loan (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bennett, Patricia Edgar, Jane Scott and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Vietnamese born, Lindy, is adopted by an Australian family who believe she is an orphan. Following her fourteenth birthday, she receives a letter from her natural father. Lindy has to decide between two families and two futures, Australia or Vietnam. Part of the “Winners” Series.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Bennett, Patricia Edgar, Jane Scott and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Winners : Just friends
results.creator_credit: Michael Pattinson, Jane Ballantyne and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Winners Series”.
Susan has just moved to a new part of town. It’s school holidays and she goes to practice her skills at the local roller rink. Buzz, the Prince of the rink, spots the talented newcomer and moves in on her. Susan joins Buzz and his gang - but she doesn’t know what she is letting herself in for. Rated: G

results.title: We call it paradise
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description: Niree Creed presents this portrait of Garden Island, 6 km. south of Perth and the effect the construction of HMAS Stirling, a naval base, has had on the island and on the town of Rockingham. The construction of the base caused some controversy as squatters, who had lived there for many years, were removed in the process. This film, produced by Defence Public Relations emphasises the benefits the base has brought to the local community.

results.title: Tor Schwanck: gold and silversmith
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”
Metal-work has been in Tor Schwanck’s family since the 15th century. He is an artisan trained in all aspects of metal-work. Schwanck uses non-precious metals as well as gold and silver. All the designs are originals, and he tours, exhibits and receives commissions for his work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Green Fingers: Drainage
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Drainage’, gardener Rod Cantrill describes the importance of well-drained soil in the home garden. Cantrill demonstrates how to lay agricultural drainage pipes to remove excess water from the soil, and how to raise garden beds as an alternative method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Welcome to my home
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the Aboriginal people of Weipa South since the time white men first arrived in 1606. The early influence of church and government is shown using historic footage and interviews with Aboriginal community leaders. Examines Aboriginal life there today and the interaction with the European settlement, which was established at Weipa to mine the bauxite deposit.

results.title: Phenakistiscope discs
results.brief_description: The phenakistiscope is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc is fitted to the device and when seen through the slots, comes to life.

constellations_primary.name: Defying gravity (phenakistoscope)
constellations_primary.description: Walking on the walls and dancing on the ceiling.

results.description:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistiscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
description_for_label:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistiscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
